title: Generation of gene-of-interest double allele knockout clones in primary human T cells by CRISPR
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Separate and activate primary naïve T cells
Timing: 3 days
Obtain pure activated mature T cells for genome editing.
Obtain human blood samples from volunteers or blood bank.
Separate human peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) from the blood sample.
Pre-warm density gradient medium (Ficoll) to room temperature around 25°C before use.
Transfer blood sample to a 50 mL Falcon tube and dilute 1:2 with PBS.
Add Ficoll to another Falcon tube.
Refer to the table below for the blood sample, PBS, Ficoll volume and tube size.
table:files/protocols_protocol_2822_5.csv
Pipette the diluted blood sample down along the side of the tube gently. The blood sample will stay above the density gradient medium.
Spin at 1,200 × g for 20 min, accelerate 7, brake off, at room temperature around 25°C.
Collect the mononucleated cells at the interface between the gradient medium and upper supernatant.
Wash enriched cells by topping up with PBS. Spin at 300 × g for 10 min, normal speed, 4°C.
Wash the pellet again as in h.
Count the cell number. The PBMCs are now ready for downstream processing. Store the rest of the cells in Freezing medium (90% FBS + 10% DMSO) for future use.
Critical: The Ficoll has to be pre-warmed to reach room temperature around 25°C. Chilled Ficoll will lose the appropriate density and PBMCs won’t become separated.
Apply negative selection kits, e.g., Pan T cell isolation kit from Miltenyi Biotec (https://www.miltenyibiotec.com/SG-en/products/pan-t-cell-isolation-kithuman.html#130-096-535[href=https://www.miltenyibiotec.com/SG-en/products/pan-t-cell-isolation-kithuman.html#130-096-535]) or EasySep™ Human T Cell Enrichment Kit from STEMCELL (https://www.stemcell.com/products/easysep-human-t-cell-isolation-kit.html[href=https://www.stemcell.com/products/easysep-human-t-cell-isolation-kit.html]). Count T cell number, and they are ready for activation. Store the rest of the cells in Freezing medium for future use.
Note: Negative selection is preferred so that the T cells will not be labeled or pre-activated before adding anti-CD3/CD28 Dynabeads.

Prepare anti-CD3/CD28 Dynabeads or suitable alternative for T cell activation.
Every 25 μL of bead solution can be used for activation of 1 × 106 T cells: use a T cell:bead ratio of 1:1.
Draw amount of beads solution according to the cell number for activation and add equal volume of buffer (PBS with 0.1% BSA, 2 mM EDTA, pH 7.5), or at least 1 mL, and mix (vortex for 5 s, or keep on a roller for at least 5 min).
Place the tube on a magnet for 1 min and discard the supernatant.
Remove the tube from the magnet and resuspend the washed beads with equal volume of culture medium as the initial beads volume.
Beads are ready to be used.
Mix washed beads and T cells evenly at a concentration of 1 × 106 T cells/mL. Supplement with human IL-2 at 100 U/mL.
Activate the T cells with beads in 37°C incubator for 60 h.
Genome editing and HDR gene insertion
Timing: 2 h
Insert gene selection markers into target gene locus.
Add 1 mL of T cell culture medium into one well of a 12 well plate and incubate at 37°C to pre-warm the medium.
Perform PCR on the HDR donor DNA fragment, containing LHA-selection gene marker-RHA, from HDR template plasmid template. The PCR reagents and running programs are shown in “materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment]”. Troubleshooting 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.1].
Prepare RNP solutions for electroporation.
Mix crRNA and tracrRNA and run duplex cooling program according to “materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment]”.
Add Cas9 protein to the duplexed gRNA and incubate at 37°C for 20 min.
Centrifuge the 1 × 106 T cells at 90 × g for 10 min at room temperature around 25°C. Remove supernatant completely.
Resuspend the T cell pellet carefully in 100 μL of Nucleofector® Solution.

Mix RNP solutions with the 2 μg donor DNA fragment for at least 30 s. Combine 100 μL of cell suspension with RNP-DNA mixture, transfer the suspension into a cuvette.
Note: The sequence of adding RNP, DNA, and cell solution will affect the editing efficiency. The RNP and DNA is suggested to be mixed before the cell solution is added.
Select the appropriate Nucleofector® Program EH-115 in the 4D Lonza electroporator.
Add 500 μL of the pre-equilibrated culture medium from the prepared 12 well plate to the cuvette and gently add the cell sample back to the well dropwise.
Critical: Avoid any harsh operations, such as repeated aspiration, be as gentle as possible. Harsh operations will induce cell death.
Put into the 37°C incubator for 15 min.
Add IL-2 (500 U/mL) to each well and culture until confluent in the 12-well plate.
Optional: HDR enhancer can be added to further enhance the insertion efficiency.12[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib12]
The HDR gene insertion efficiency can be observed after 48 h.
Clone isolation and gene expression validation
Timing: 1 week
Generate GOI double allele knockout T cell clones.
Check the selection gene marker expression, for example expression of CAR-His and CARMyc.1[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1] See Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]. Troubleshooting 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.3], Troubleshooting 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.5].

Figure 3. Clone isolation and gene expression validation
(A) Expression of gene markers after HDR insertion. CAR-Myc and CAR-His are used to indicate GOI disruption at different allele. LCK gene is used as a demonstration.
(B) Sorting and restimulation of selected clones. Double positive gene marker expressed T cells (DP) and single positive gene marker expressed T cells (CAR-His or CAR-myc) are sorted and restimulated individually.
(C) PCR results of editing DNA region. The single positive gene marker expressed T cells are used for illustration, and both inserted CAR gene and WT DNA fragment can be detected.

(D) Western blot of LCK expression in DP and SP T cells. The data are retrieved and reorganized from the study by Wu et al.1[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1]
Sort the double selection gene marker-expressing cells by staining with fluorescent antibodies and a fluorescence flow cytometer. Culture the sorted cells and supplement with IL-2 (500 U/mL in medium).
When the sorted T cells stop or slow down their proliferation, restimulate and expand the sorted cells using irradiated PBMCs as feeder cells.13[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib13] HLA type matching is not required.
Irradiate PBMCs in 30Gy. The number of PBMCs should be slightly higher than the designated number, for irradiation will induce some cell death.
Alternatives: Mitomycin C (MMC) can be used to arrest the PBMCs proliferation. In this case, incubate PBMCs with 20 μg/mL of MMC for 1 h in a 37°C incubator. Wash the cells with PBS three times after incubation. The PBMCs are ready to use.
Mix irradiated PBMCs with sorted T cells at cell number ratio of 3:1.
Note: If the sorted cell number is few (fewer than 1 × 106 cells), add PBMCs according to the surface area. Add 3 × 106 and 1 × 106 irradiated PBMCs to one well of 6 well plate and 12 well plate respectively. If doing more strict clone selection by FACS sorting, fewer than 20 cells per well of a 96 well plate, add 2 × 105 of irradiated PBMCs per well of a 96 well plate.
Supplement the medium with 100 U/mL IL-2, 10 ng/mL IL-7, and 10 ng/mL IL-15 and 1.5 μg/mL PHA lectin. This day is designated day 0.
At day 5, T cell clusters are visible, and T cell clones are expanding. Passage the expanded T cells accordingly and maintain cell density at 1–3 × 106/mL.

Check the expression of selection gene markers. See Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3].
Note: It is important to select cells expressing both markers, as single marker-expressing cells could represent only a single allele insertion, where the expression of the protein of interest may not be completely depleted, as shown in Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3].
The GOI knockout can be validated by using primers, described at step 7 in “before you begin[href=https://www.wicell.org#before-you-begin]” session, to PCR the editing region, and by performing western blotting to examine the GOI depletion. See Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]. Troubleshooting 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.7].
Note: The PCR results should show only the band of selection gene markers. This validates the GOI knockout. The western blot should also show no GOI expression.
The validated GOI knockout clones are then ready for downstream experiments.
Culture and expand the cells until they arrest the proliferation. Freeze and aliquot the cells in freezing medium (90% FBS, 10% DMSO). The frozen cells are GOI knockout clones.
Note: The frozen cells can be revived and expanded via the same procedure described as step 20. The clones are able to be restimulated and expanded at least 5 times with similar activity in each cycle.
